title: What does the job market for data science graduates look like?
text:
The present state of the economy (as of May 2023) is uncertain at best, with some bearish analysts warning of recession while others claim it‚Äôs business as usual. A recent Forbes advisor article tracked 15 market performance metrics and rated 3 as good, 4 as neutral, and 8 as bad. Two conflicting consumer confidence surveys were listed - one rated good, the other rated bad. On the other hand, a recent nerdwallet article dated May 3rd plainly states that ‚ÄúAccording to a traditional definition, the U.S. is not currently in a recession.‚Äù
I am not an economist; Rather, I am a data science graduate student at Georgetown University‚Äôs Data Science and Analytics (DSAN) program. Since I will need to find a job after I graduate, I‚Äôd like to understand the current state of job market for data scientists. Rather than break out the machine learning algorithms to try and predict where the economy is going, I think creating some visualizations using the data provided for our mini-project might give us an intuitive sense of how the data science market looks like right now. At the very least, I hope to answer a few questions that I‚Äôve had when trying to navigate job postings.
The data provided for this mini-project comes from a web-crawling exercise that involved 11 different search terms on April 14th, 2023. These search terms were:

data scientist
data analyst
neural networks
big data and cloud computing
machine learning
reinforcement learning
deep learning
time series
time series analysis (combined with time series)
block chain
natural language processing

The searches were also divided into two categories based on their location: nationwide, and here in Washington, D.C. You can see a sample job posting below:
 

Screenshot of an example job posting. Many postings list abundant qualifications, responsibilities, and benefits.


There were a total of 823 unique job postings. From these postings, there were 458 unique job titles, which leads me to my first question.

title: What does the job market for data science graduates look like?
section: üï∏Ô∏è Untangling The Web of Job Titles
text:
üï∏Ô∏è Untangling The Web of Job Titles
Given the vast number of job titles - and 11 different search categories - I wondered which jobs I might qualify for with my degree. I‚Äôve often heard that data science graduates are prepared for a wide variety of jobs, and not to limit oneself only to jobs entitled ‚ÄúData Scientist‚Äù. To this end, I focused on the ‚ÄúQualifications‚Äù and ‚ÄúResponsibilities‚Äù sections of a the job posting. I used a community detection algorithm, combined with some network visualization tools, to determine whether the words used to describe these positions are really as different as their titles might indicate.

A network of qualifications ‚Ä¶

    



Note that you can click on a shape to highlight its connections, then move and zoom the chart as needed for clarity. Squares represent search terms, while circles represent noun phrases associated with that search term.


Depending on the algorithm I used, I found anywhere between 1 and 3 distinct groups of qualifications amongst the search terms. In this final iteration, we can see that there are three communities of listed qualifications.

Yellow Group - Math and Statistics: Primary qualifications explicitly reference math and statistics, as well as regression and R, the statistical programming language. These are deep learning, time series, and reinforcement learning jobs.

Red Group - High Experience: These jobs reference experience, skills, ‚Äòa related field‚Äô, and a master‚Äôs degree. These are more specialized machine learning, natural language processing (NLP), and block chain jobs.
Purple Group - Computer Science Heavy: References more software-focused programming languages such as C++, Java, and Scala. These are the big data and neural networks jobs.

If you click on the nodes (circles/squares) of the network, you can see that even though distinct groups are formed, there is a lot of overlap in the qualifications. The main qualifications that are not covered in out program are the more software-oriented programming languages such as C++, Java, and Scala.


‚Ä¶ and a network of responsibilities


    


 

We can see that the responsibilities listed in the job postings also form 3 similar groups.


Turning out attention to the responsibilities listed in the job postings, we once again are left with three groups using this specific algorithm.
My impression of these groups is as follows:

Yellow Group - Client-Facing ML: Responsiblities include creating Machine Learning (ML) models, with an emphasis on providing value to customers. These are Deep Learning, Data Science, and Machine Learning jobs.

Red Group - Technical-Managerial: Responsiblities that focus on training, management, and providing technical expertise. These jobs include Big Data and Cloud Computing, Block Chain, and more advanced Reinforcement Learning.

Purple Group - Collaborative Development: This group references more ‚Äòsoft skills‚Äô such as collaboration, development, and design. While these are still very technical positions such as Neural Networks and NLP, it often takes a big team to build these models!

Overall, there is heavy overlap for the qualifications and responsibilities associated with each search term. The answer to the question ‚ÄúAre the qualifications and responsibilities for these jobs very different?‚Äù is: probably not. Fortunately, it looks like our program prepares us very well for the majority of these positions.

title: What does the job market for data science graduates look like?
section: ü¶∏‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è With great responsibility comes great benefits?
text:
ü¶∏‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è With great responsibility comes great benefits?
The language in which a job opportunity is packaged varies greatly from company to company. Some postings are described extensively, while other simply list a few meagre bullet points. The extent to which the amount of qualifications, responsibilities, and benefits reflect the true nature of a position is unclear. However, as a prospective applicant, my intuition would be that a job with more listed qualifications and responsibilities should also have more benefits. At the very least, one would expect companies that are more verbose in their recruitment would have more bullet points in each category: qualifications, responsibilities, and benefits.
To answer this question, I tallied the number of bullet points in each category for all of the positions that listed values for all three:



                                                




In this plot, the size of the bubble is scaled to the number of listed responsibilities. The position on the bottom (x) axis reflects the number of qualifications listed on the job posting, while the position on the left (y) axis marks the number of listed responsibilities. Use the dropdown menu on the top left to filter by the type of job, and mouse over a bubble to reveal more information about that position!


In many cases, there doesn‚Äôt appear to be much of a relationship between the number of listed responsibilities, qualifications, and benefits. I admit that this is not the most rigorous way to analyze whether what employers desire in candidates is commensurate with their benefits, however this may pose a perceptual problem for employers who are trying to attract talent. For example, a prospective applicant might look at a job posting with 40 listed responsibilities and only 2 benefits - as one company did - and immediately decide not to apply to that position.



                                                




A correlation matrix between the number of qualifications, responsibilities, and benefits.


Looking at the correlations between the three variables, we can see that the relationship differs by the job type. NLP jobs stand out with a solid 0.47 correlation between the number of listed benefits and qualifications. All other correlations are around the 0 to 0.3 range, except for time series which is misleading due to its sample size of 2.
Out of the 823 job postings in our dataset, only 464 of them listed their benefits up front. In general, the number of listed requirements for a position are not matched by the number of benefits offered. The amount of information provided for each category should be considered by both employers and job applicants to better set expectations, facilitate greater transparency, and improve the hiring process for both parties.

title: What does the job market for data science graduates look like?
text:
üó∫Ô∏è Mapping Salaries
Continuing with our theme of transparency, I imagine much consideration goes into whether a salary should be listed on a posting. According to LinkedIn, 91% of job seekers said seeing a salary range on a job posting affects their decision to apply for a job. In our sample, only 133 postings listed a salary range - approximately 15% of all jobs.
Most of the salaries are listed as a range with a minimum and a maximum. To visualize the range of salaries, I created a map of the job postings. There are two overlapping circles for all jobs that posted a salary range - the inner circle is scaled to the minimum salary, and the outer circle is scaled to the maximum salary.
In-person jobs are shown at their listed location, and are displayed by default. Only the city and state were provided, so the locations reflect the city, but not the actual office address. A small amount of noise was added to prevent jobs in the same city from overlapping. Remote jobs were placed in random locations throughout the continental US, and are not shown by default. Click the ‚ÄúRemote‚Äù checkbox on the top right to see those positions.


Make this Notebook Trusted to load map: File -> Trust Notebook




A map of the jobs that listed a salary. The inner circle represents the minimum salary listed, and the outer circle represents the maximum salary listed. Click on a circle to reveal more information about that job. Scroll to zoom in on a region and see the individual jobs (try the DC metro area!). Jobs with an hourly wage listed were converted to yearly salary ranges by multiplying the wage by the approximate number of hours worked in a year (2,080 for a 40 hour work week). Remote jobs were randomly placed within the US, and can be toggled using the checkbox in the top right corner. Locations only reflect the city and state listed in the posting, not actual addresses.


Examining this map, some trends become apparent. Most of the positions have a fair amount of room for negotiation. On average, the maximum salary is $35,000 or 61% more than the minimum salary, but there is considerable variance. See the remote Fintech Recruiters job, with a minimum of $100,000 and a maximum of $500,000. A prospective applicant‚Äôs perception of a posting may be impacted by the listed range of a salary. A fixed salary might seem rigid and convey a sense of strict salary structure, whereas a position with a very broad range may seem confusing or too good to be true.
We can also see that in-person jobs tend to be similar within a region. Looking at San Francisco as an example, we can see that the salaries seem to be within the same approximate range of $100,000 - $250,000. Whether a salary is similar to other salaries in the region can also contribute to a prospective applicant‚Äôs decision to apply for the position. Jobs with salaries much lower than the regional standard may be completely passed over.
Choosing whether to post a salary is a significant decision for an employer. In my opinion, I think that listing a salary range is best; this sets expectations for the applicant and promotes fairness in negotiation. The talent pool available to the employer will also be larger, since more people will want to apply to a job that posts a salary within their desired range.

title: What does the job market for data science graduates look like?
text:
üîé Conclusions
Let‚Äôs summarize the key insights from this mini-project:

Data science jobs are often called something other than ‚ÄúData Scientist.‚Äù Only 21 of the positions in our dataset actually had ‚ÄúData Scientist‚Äù in the job title. Despite using 11 different search terms, the qualifications and responsibilities for these categories heavily overlapped in our network analysis. Data science graduates should not hesitate to apply to positions that do not explicitly mention data science for fear of being unqualified.
Employers should be mindful of the types of information they provide for a job posting. There was not a strong relationship between the amount of responsibilities/qualifications listed and the amount of benefits listed. While I simply counted the number of bullet points, and those are likely not a good proxy for the true nature of the job, it may impact a job seeker‚Äôs perception. If tens of responsibilities are listed but few benefits, it may look like the job asks for more than it provides, and reduce interest in the job.
Listing a salary range on a job posting is an impactful decision. Job seekers can easily compare salaries to similar jobs in their area. If the salaries are significantly less than comparable positions, this will discourage applicants. Posting a salary range can convey a sense of flexibility and willingness to compensate based on individual factors. If the range is small, it could suggest a fixed salary structure that may be undesirable. Huge salary ranges may make the posting more confusing (maybe the company is hiring at different levels) - or worse, it could make the job posting seem like it is fake. On average, a maximum salary that is 25-75% more than the minimum will seem reasonable.

In building this project, I‚Äôve learned a lot about the types of jobs available to a data science graduate like myself. I feel more confident in applying to jobs with unfamiliar titles. Finally, I feel more confident in knowing what to look for in a posting‚Äôs qualifications, responsibilities, benefits, and salary. Thanks for reading!

title: Methodology and Notes

Take me back to the report!
On this page, I briefly summarize some of the techniques used to generate the visualizations in the report. All code will be linked on my github after the project is de-anonymized.

title: Methodology and Notes
text:
Network Analysis
Section name: ‚ÄúUntangling The Web of Job Titles‚Äù
These network visualizations were generated using a combination of the textnets and pyviz packages. Creating the network visualization required a few steps:

Text preparation: The text data is cleaned by removing stop words, tokenizing to noun phrases, and calculating the term frequency - inverse document frequency (TF-IDF). TF-IDF is a technique used for determining important words in a document. The noun phrases are filtered based on their TF-IDF score.
Network building: The documents and noun phrases are plotted as nodes, with the documents (search terms) represented as squares, and the noun phrases represented as circles. An edge (line) is drawn between nodes that co-occur.

Community detection: The nodes are colored by their community. Community detection was completed using a Reichardt and Bornholdt‚Äôs Potts model. My understanding is that this model was appropriate because is flexible and allows for overlapping communities.

title: Methodology and Notes
text:
Qualifications, Responsibilities, and Benefits
Section name: ‚ÄúGreat Responsibilities, Great Benefits?‚Äù
The data for the visualizations in this section was generated by counting the number of bullet points for each category listed in the job posting. The colors of the bubble represent the search term, while the area of the circle is scaled to the number of benefits listed. The values in the correlation matrix are simply Pearson‚Äôs correlation coefficients. Both plots were primarily generated using the plotly package in python.

title: Methodology and Notes
text:
Map
Section name: ‚ÄúMapping Salaries‚Äù
Since the data were quite messy, a number of visualization choices needed to be made. Here are the main decisions:

Finding locations and adding noise: Jobs were either remote (listed as ‚Äúanywhere‚Äù or ‚Äúunited states‚Äù), or they were listed at a location in city, state abbreviation format.

For remote jobs, coordinates were randomly assigned to a location in the continental US. A bounding box was created in GeoJSON for this purpose. Most of the remote jobs will appear in the central US, since drawing a bigger box often led to some jobs being located in the ocean. To avoid any confusion, the remote jobs are not displayed by default, so the user must click on the ‚Äúremote‚Äù box to show those jobs.
For in-person jobs, the coordinates were located using the nominatim API. Since a number of jobs were listed in the same city, I needed to add a small amount of noise to the coordinates to avoid overlap (about a tenth of a degree).

Yearly/Hourly: Some positions were listed as hourly wage jobs. These were converted into yearly salaries by multiplying the wage by 2,080, which is the approximate number of hours worked in a year for a full-time employee. This way, the jobs could be compared on the same scale.
Markers: The green markers were scaled to 1/5000 of the actual salary. The concentric circles were used to show a minimum and a maximum salary range. A popup was generated to provide more information about the position.
The map: The map was created with folium, and used a template called ‚Äúdark matter‚Äù to match the website aesthetic.
